description:
Objective: Be the first racing to position '130'
'Move by turns' game from the 1910's in Germany.

A plastic frog has to be flipped onto a big board showing a large pool with different animals. Depending on the area the frog is landing on you may move forward (acc. number) or backwards (snake, stork...). When you reach space 120 or higher you are safe, but the target must be reached with a matching jump.

Pride and Glory: The Peloponnesian War is a strategy game set during a war in Ancient Greece. Players take control of the cities of Athens and Sparta and train soldiers, construct buildings, capture cities, and engage in epic battles for the future of Greece. Players control their empire from a full campaign perspective on the game board, but once a battle begins, players can command their soldiers in tactical, unit-by-unit combat on separate battlefield maps.

Game turns are divided into the four seasons of the year. Each season has four phases in which players: 1) Build up their empire by recruiting units, constructing buildings and conducting diplomacy. 2) Move their units around the Campaign Map and besiege cities. 3) Engage in battle and command their soldiers in tactical, simulation combat. 4) Protect themselves against revolts of the people and the stormy seas of the Aegean.

Every triumph brings your city more glory, and closer to victory, until all Greece kneels before you. Throughout the game players earn things called Glory Points for doing things like capturing cities, winning battles – even just by proving that your enemy is too cowardly to come out and fight. Whichever player is the first to get to 75 Glory Points wins the game.

It's a fight to reach the summit faster than the other player! The spinner determines the colour of the holes you can use to attach your climbers' limbs each turn. The more risky movements you made, leaving limbs unsecured, the quicker you'll ascend, but also, the easier the other player would make you fall if he lands in the same spot from the other side and kicks you out of the hole. The first player to take his two climbers to the summit, wins the game.

It’s lunch time! The mechanical chef maniacally spins in the middle of the game board and throws them all over the place, and the players manually move their plates so they can get the pizzas delivered to them. But they should be careful! Not all the pizzas are well cooked and if they get one half-cooked, they lose points. In the end, the player with the most points (counting the good pizzas minus the half-cooked ones), wins the game.

Ah-Sitake HA! The ninja battlin', card spinnin', flingin' flangin' action game of well, battling ninjas, spinning cards, and flanging flingings.

Simultaneously choose your battle focus card, then toss it out onto the table and see whether your attack attacked, your counter countered, your block blocked, your throw threw, or your weakness got punched squarely in the junk!  Battle multiple opponents at the same time.  But be careful!  A successful attack on one opponent may leave you exposed in a very sensitive spot!  With every angle there is an equal and opposite re-angle... and yours may just be your undoing!

Battle your friends until they become your enemies!  If anyone is left standing after one round, special attack and block cards come into play to give those that are behind the ability to hopefully SAVE their behind, or more efficiently KICK someone else's!

Are you ready for some fast-paced, ninja animal, card battling?  Oh you think so, do you?  Well, you'll just have to find out.  I say to you, sir (or ma'am), "Ah-Sitake HA!"

In Barking Up The Wrong Tree, players must try to collect the most trees, preferably of different types. To do this, they place dogs barking up the trees of their choice, and the most dogs wins the tree. Normally a player can place only one breed of dog per tree, but if a player plays a cat card, then more dogs can join the throng.

The game is played over five lively game rounds, with increasing numbers of dogs, cats and trees available each round.

Deceptively simple, this game works a treat.

Landships is a stand alone game for 2-6 players. It includes 6 new Spurs and Sprockets decks and introduces a new set of rules that includes the Fire Away, projectile attack. Players may combine it with the basic Spurs and Sprockets decks or the Revolutionary decks. The game decks also include artwork used with the new Fire Away rules.

Spurs and Sprockets is a perfect information, abstract strategy game. Players each have the same eight tiles/cards that they take turns placing into a grid, in an attempt to link three or four in a row. There is no board in Spurs and Sprockets so the grid grows organically, based on the placement of tiles. The grid also varies in size and dimensions based on the number of players.

This Spurs and Sprockets game comes with 48 tiles/cards and rules for many different ways of playing, ranging from a simple Tic-Tac-Toe-like game where players gain 8 points for four in a row and 3 points for each set of three in a row, to a game where every placement of a tile/card may result in an attack and removal of another.

From the publisher's website:

Target... 11 O’Clock... FIRE!!!

Welcome to the FURY of the West Front!

Tank on Tank: West Front is the 2nd edition of Peter Bogdasarian’s hit game Tank on Tank. A game that can be learned quickly and played in less then an hour, Tank on Tank: West Front depicts deadly tactical ground combat in 1944 and 1945 during World War II.

New in Tank on Tank: West Front are rules for improved positions, armored infantry, airstrikes
and supply trucks. Experience the tactical flavor of World War II tank battles like never before.

Tank on Tank: West Front is a tactical game on the light side.
Tank on Tank: West Front includes Shermans, Wolverines, Priests, King Tigers, Panthers, Mark IVs, as well as the infantry and anti-tank guns that fought alongside them. Now on gigantic one-inch counters.
If you’ve been looking for a simple game to try your leadership abilities, or something to introduce a young commander to war gaming, Tank on Tank: West Front is the answer for you.

Heroic Hustle is a fully cooperative team-based experience for 2-4 players. The superheroes (that's you), lead the other heroes of the city into battle to protect a city on the edge of destruction.

A wide range of threats will endanger the city every round, and it's up to the players to nullify them before they can launch an attack. By pairing up your heroic strengths to the weaknesses of your enemies, you'll be able to arrest the attacking forces.

These threats are only the first layer of danger, though. There's always a supervillain in the background working against Cascade City throughout the entire game. Even worse, the more progress you make towards foiling their schemes, the angrier the supervillain gets, and the more dangerous they become.

As if all of that wasn't enough to keep your heroic hands busy, plot twists will change the way the game is played from round to round. One round might see the villains sporting shiny new weapons, while in the next your entire team might be turned into gorillas! As the supervillain's master plan unfolds, these dynamic events will force your team to work together and adapt your strategies.

Thankfully, your elite team has plenty of resources to combat these threats. Some of the heroes in your team work better with each other and can join forces for massive, game-changing unite attacks! You can even summon entire supergroups to show the villains what havoc really means! Not only that, but the denizens of Cascade City are ready to fight for their homes. Whether it's the plucky news team alerting the populous of danger, the tireless repair crews rebuilding the city after vicious attacks, or the dashing Kelly Courier who risks life and limb to help your team get to where they need to be. And if all else fails, each player has their own special superpowers that they can unleash when the situation is dire!

The ã‚´ãƒªãƒ†ã‚£ã‚¢ (Goritaire) deck consists of two types of cards: gorillas and bananas. To win the game, you need to assemble at least seven gorillas in a row — but you need to keep the banana supply flowing or else the gorillas won't last.

Description from the publisher:

To Andor! Chada the archeress and Thorn the fighter travel from the northern end of Silberland to the southern coast of the island. The dwarfs there will help them cross back to Andor. On their voyage, thrilling adventures and new challenges await them. They will reach safe harbor only if they stick together, yet a sinister enemy follows their steps.

Die Legenden von Andor: Chada & Thorn, a two-player cooperative card game set in the world of Andor, tells the story of two heroes returning from the north (the setting for Die Legenden von Andor: Die Reise in den Norden). The players may choose one of four ready-to-play adventures, and the placement of the tiles allows them to experience new routes and different challenges.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German city of Neuss. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Varuhuset ("The Department Store") is a game simulating the excitement and everyday hardships of department store salesmen. Players try to rent different departments and disks within the department store at as favorably prices as possible, with the hope of making good commerce later on during the game.

Luck plays a part in this game, as prices for buying and selling is partially randomized through card drawing. Another important mechanic is the initial auctioning for renting the different departments, which then become the main source of income for the different players.

The game ends when the first two (!) players leave the department store; then the richest salesman win!

Trivia game with (some tricky) questions related to the Hunsrück, a region situated in Germany, located between the cities Trier, Coblenz, Bingen & Saarbrücken. 
The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Trivia game with questions related to the German federal state Hessen. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. 
Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the region Sauerland, located in Germany. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Trivia game with questions related to the German city of Ludwigsburg. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. 
Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Great Scott! - The Game of Mad Invention is a Victorian themed card game of rival mad inventors.

In Great Scott!, the whimsical 19th century parlour game that never was, 3-5 players build five card inventions with an eye to victory in the inventor’s contest at the Great Exhibition. Combine Animal, Mineral, and Vegetable assets with Destructive, Productive, and Transportive concepts to create one of the greatest inventions not known to mankind!

In a game of Great Scott!, players draft cards & add components to their invention. Matching sets of asset & concept cards give bonus points, but the biggest prizes are awarded for alliteration. Then, when your invention is finished, explain what it does and how it works to get extra points from the other inventors.

Great Scott! is easy to learn, fast to play, and is guaranteed to amuse!

Will your Bedazzling Bat Borne Brass Balloon outdo your rival’s Diabolical Dynamite Driven Duck Dispatcher? Perhaps, if you play your cards right…

Consider carefully; clever card combinations and amusing alliterative amalgamations bring bountiful bonuses!

For Her Majesty, and for science!

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German city of Leipzig. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. 
Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Trivia game with questions related to the German region of Schwäbische-Alb . The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. 
Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Trivia game with questions related to the German city of Saarbrücken. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. 
Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

The year is 1607. The place, Virginia. The Indians & the English settlers have been at odds ever since the villainous John Ratcliffe & his men arrived to search for gold. Chief Powhatan's daughter Pocahontas & the English Captain Jon Smith want you to bring together all their Powhatan & English friends. Gramdmother Willow will help as yo gather Meeko & Flit, Powhatan & Nakoma, & Thomas, Wiggins & Lon. The first player to overcome John Ratcliffe (& his pampered pooch Percy) & collect all the friends will bring peace to the forest - & win the game.
Ages 5 and up.

Each player begins the game with a Pocahontas card and a John Smith card. On your turn, draw a card and if it is one of Pocahontas' friends or John's friends, place the card face up below that character. If you already have one of those friends, place the card in the Friends Discard pile.
Special cards include John Ratcliffe, Percy and Grandmother Willow. 
If Ratcliffe is drawn, you must turn John or Pocahontas face down. When turned face down, one of their friends must be placed in the Friends Discard pile and any friends drawn while they are face down are also discarded.
If Percy is drawn, you play him on an opponent and they must turn over their Pocahontas or John card.
If Grandmother Willow is drawn all face down John Smith and/or Pocahontas get turned face up again.
The first person to get a complete set of the two Friends groups is the winner.

From the publisher:

Fifty new side splitting Curses that will make you beg for more and 50 new crazy "challenge cards" that are easy to do but hard to watch without laughing. Also 8 NEW Ding Cards! You can mix the new curses with the original curses decks and use it with the original rules or you can play More Curses as a stand alone game. Whatever you do keep playing and keep laughing; it's good for you.

La ovejas y el Dragón ("The sheep and the Dragon") is a game for children.

In a fantasy world, where many sheep escaped the castle, shepherds have the mission to find them and bring them back home. In the adventure they will find objects that help and enemies with which to fight. In turn, the great and almost invincible dragon roams throughout the kingdom seeking to steal sheep and take them to their cave.

The aim of the players is to recover the sheep, bring them back and avoid at all costs the dragon, though, if some brave shepherd manages to defeat the dragon in combat, it will be consecrated the great savior and win the game immediately.
If no defeat the dragon, the pastor with more points (for accumulation of sheep) has wins.

The game mechanics are simple, each turn pastors must perform two actions, move and look. To move roll a die (1d4), after completing its movement they can search the area where it is located and there, stealing a card from the appropriate deck as the area will reveal your search. The areas investigated can not be investigated in the future. In his search you will find objects, events, enemies and sheep. Every sheep has a value in coins (VPs), the pastor must take the sheep back to the castle to win the reward.

As a bonus action, if a pastor result is an 1 in movement (as in the Talisman), after completing their actions must "activate" the dragon.
When the exploration markers are finished, or when the dragon is defeated, the game ends.

This was a project borne out of nostalgia for the photographs from the old Wargames World and Wargames Illustrated as well stories from various expatriate wargamers who moved to Australia and re-told great stories about fighting the Mahdi with Peter Gilder at the Wargames Holiday Centre.

After gathering information, sheets, original source tables and other files, the rules have been put together as close to the Gilder style of game as possible.

The Umpire plays the part of the Mahdists and their entry, troop type, disposition and general attitude is determined by the situation and random dice.  The events cards play the part of creating an additional element of the unknown into every game so that the same scenario can only rarely ever play the same way twice.  Mahdists are on larger style crafted bases for ease of movement and each base represents 100 men (scale of 1:10) even though there could be as few as 5 figures on a base if desired.

The Imperials are all played by the gamers.  "Us" against the Umpire is great fun!

This is also the perfect game for Solo play.

Organisation is based on five companies to a regiment each company consisting of 12 figures.  Once again, you can use 12 or as few figures as you wish as figures are never removed from bases but marked off on an easy to use Roster sheet.

Cavalry work in squadrons and Troops and artillery batteries in sections up.

The game comes with a 44 page gloss laminated booklet and a deck of random event cards. Six blank cards are included so players can tailor events and circumstances to suit your their collections and gaming dispositions.

Trivia game with questions related to the German city of Grevenbroich. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each.
Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German city of Osnabrück. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each.
Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

The monkey players in Viva! Coconots want to grab coconuts from the field, with those coconuts ideally lying in a straight line.

To set up the game, place the "Las-nut" card in the center of a 3x3 grid, then shuffle the other coconut cards and lay eight of them in the surrounding spaces of the grid, removing any unused cards from the game. The coconut cards have powers on them that come into effect when that card is active during the game.

The game lasts nine rounds. Each player has a deck of monkey cards numbered 1-10, and to start play, they each shuffle their deck, lay two cards at random face down in the front of them (looking at them whenever they like), then take a hand of three cards. In a round, the players look at the coconut card for this round (as indicated on the Las-nut card), choose a monkey card in hand, then reveal them simultaneously. If two or more players lay down the same card, they're out for the round. After taking into account the coconut's power, whoever played the highest card wins the round and places a token on the card.

The Las-nut card is claimed in the final round, with whoever has the highest total in the two cards set aside claiming it. (These cards can possibly be swapped during play.)

If a player has ever placed three tokens in a line on the grid, that player wins immediately. If this doesn't happen, whoever has placed the most tokens (with the Las-nut counting as two) wins.

A rather simple game following the 3-4 day track of convoys from Gibraltar and Alexandria to Malta in the face of Stukas, torpedobombers, high-altitude Italian bombers, MAS torpedo boats, U-boats and Italian submarines, and the Italian navy.

Battleships and carriers (usually) in single ship units, cruiser divisions, and convoys.  10th Army's/Afrika Korps' progress ... or retreat ... inversely proportionate to Malta's strength.

One representational convoy each may start from G and A per season - 11 seasons total, unless Malta falls or Alamein or Tripoli fall.

Summer 1940 and Operation Pedestal (Summer 1942) scenarios or campaign game.

Players must master power, speed, and precision to keep up with the frenetic marble shooting play in the B-Daman Break Bomber Battlefield arena, inspired by the B-Daman Season 1 TV series. Players start on opposite sides as they shoot at the rows of blocks in the center of the arena. Blasting away yellow blocks reveal red blocks. The player that blasts three out of five red blocks into the opponents’ territory wins.

The B-DAMAN figures are definitely toys of this generation. They are tied-in with the B-DAMAN Crossfire TV series; there are QR codes on the figures, and an associated app is available, so you can continue the battle online. Yet, even with all these new twists, it is still a classic marble shooter battling game at its core.

Set includes one deluxe target unit with 25 blocks, completely enclosed arena walls, two B-Daman figures, two B-Daman Wide Magazine Accessory pieces, 1 customization tool, 16 B-Da Marbles, 4 Ultra B-Da Marbles, 2 collector cards, a sheet of consumer-applied labels, and instructions. Each of the Wide Magazine accessories takes ten marbles at a time, so players can do less loading and more blasting.

The first player with a palace to amass 12 victory points (VP) in constructed buildings and captive Emperors in Ekö wins the game.

To set up, fill the board with all the pawns, placed at random. Before starting the game, each player can exchange their Emperor pawn with another of their pawns elsewhere on the board. On your turn, you must do both phases in this order: the action phase, then the reinforcements phase. During the action phase, you must perform one single action:


    Move: Move to an empty space, regroup or attack; you can attack only a stack of enemy pieces that contains strictly fewer pieces than the attacking stack — except that a stack of four pieces can be attacked and destroyed by a stack of one piece.



    Construct: You can construct only one building per space; subsequent construction on the same space replaces the existing building. Each terrain type allows specific types of construction. In order to construct a building on an empty space or on a space already containing one of your buildings, you must sacrifice pieces from a single stack adjacent to this construction space. 


Once per turn, you can take an extra action by sacrificing three stackable pieces. A stack that contains the Emperor can attack an enemy stack even if it contains an equal number of pieces, and even if it contains another Emperor. Each enemy Emperor you have captive is worth 3 VP.

During the reinforcements phase, if you have pieces in your reserve, you must return at least one piece to play if you can.
You can place up to three pieces onto a single stack of your color on the board (never on an empty space), respecting the following rule: You cannot place reinforcements on a stack if it is adjacent to another player's building.

The game ends immediately when a player has amassed 12 VP by adding up the values of his buildings on the board and any Emperors they have captured — each village is worth 1VP, each tower 2VP, and each castle and captured Emperor 3VP — and they have at least one palace. Alternatively, if a player is the only one with pieces remaining on the board (making reinforcement impossible for the other players), they win.

The game comes with three decks of cards --- one easy, one medium, and one hard. Every card in each deck describes an animal. Each player in turn chooses a deck; another player draws a card from that deck and reads the description on the card. The listening player tries to guess the animal that is described. Correct Easy answers score 50 points, Medium 75 points, and Hard 100 points. A player must reach exactly 500 points to win.

Many, many sunsets ago, it started as a card game. It is a game about an armadillo in a handheld video game. Two twins, who had been playing the game since the womb, decided to create such a game by designing a system they deemed the Intento RiiPlay. It may have had monotone graphics but it had a cool level editor.

However, the prototype was hijacked by their rival creators and codenamed the Mega Raystation. Soon after, the project was apprehended by the government which saw the name as a threat to national security. Nonetheless, Intendo went on, and its founders continued playing RIC O’ Chet, the armored ‘dillo card game.

You too can play this card game! Players create a level from their level cards for their opponent to beat. Each players level starts as 3 cards with controller button icons that must match the icons on their editor cards to score.

As cards are scored from the left, cards shift just as they would in a side scrolling platformer. The creator of the level uses their editor cards to determine which level cards are placed next. The first player to score all 12 of their opponents level cards wins the round and the opponent loses a health. If  a player loses all health, they have lost the game!

The battle is about to begin. There are four families with one goal: power. In the end, after all the shootings and the thefts of gold, only one Boss will remain to rule over the city.

In Pizza, Spaghetti e Mandolino each player takes the role of one family. The player will have to defeat the rival families in order to become the one and undisputed ruler of the city. There are two ways to achieve this:

    Kill the opponents' Bosses.
    Steal all the gold bars from the opponents' treasury.


Both are legitimate  methods: After all, it's a matter of style.
Players take turns buying and playing aggression cards and sending family members to steal or shoot the opponents' Bosses, until only all players but one is eliminated.


La battaglia sta per cominciare. Quattro famiglie, un unico obbiettivo: il potere. Tra spari e furti di lingotti d'oro, solo un Boss diventerà il padrone assoluto della città.

In Pizza, Spaghetti e Mandolino ogni giocatore rappresenta una famiglia rigorosamente italiana; dovrà sconfiggere le famiglie avversarie per diventare il padrone assoluto della città.  Per farlo ha due modi:

    uccidere i Boss degli avversari;
    lasciare gli avversari senza lingotti d'oro, che rappresentano la ricchezza della famiglia accumulata dopo tanti anni di lavoro.


Entrambi i metodi sono validi per eliminare gli altri giocatori. In fondo è tutta una questione di stile: decidere di vincere sporcandosi o meno le mani.

TRAP! is a fast-paced, deductive, dice-rolling, card game system for 2-4 players in which you're trying to ensnare the biggest sets of creatures over the course of five rounds.

Each TRAP! game is a standalone item, but they are compatible with one another and parts can be combined to create a personalized TRAP!

A game box forms a board that consist of tree, meadow and a lake.
And there is 14 chips that have pictures of animals, plants and things that child must put on the right spot of the board.
When all chips has been placed on their right spot on the board, the game ends.

Version for older kids, is that every of a two players has 4 spots on tree for himself, and chips are face down. Each player draws one chip and puts it on its place. Whoever puts chips on its 4 spot of a tree wins the game.
Harder version of a game is that all chips that are not placed on a tree are returned back face down next to unused chips.

Trivia game with questions related to the German composer Richard Wagner. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. 
Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Trivia game with questions related to German citations. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. 
Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Europe of the Dark Ages was a treacherous landscape of shifting alliances, warfare, and betrayal. Among the most feared peoples of this time were the Northmen, who came from the lands of Scandinavia to pillage and conquer, without warning and without mercy. In time, the Northmen established their own kingdoms across Europe, and came to dominate many more, gathering enormous wealth and establishing lucrative trade routes.

In Saga of the Northmen, you control a clan of mighty Northmen. Each round, you will use your influence cards to try to gain control of the seven major kingdoms of Europe. You will then maneuver the armies and fleets of the kingdoms that have fallen under your sway. Use your forces wisely, and the riches of Europe are yours for the taking. But beware, there are other clans who also seek plunder and coin. Only the richest and most notorious clan will prevail!

Trivia game with questions related to the German town of Göttingen. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. 
Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Adventure game for kids set in fairy tale land where each player controls different character.

Modular board is build throughout the game while players explore different places. To move character players have to roll dice and match the color pattern on the leading ways. Meeting friends and rides helps to expend abilities and gives better chances to win fights and pass all kind of tests.

The goal is to find the enchanted princess, break the spell and bring her to the castle.

At the beginning of Shootout players receive an identity: sheriff, deputy, gunfighter, outlaw, etc. Initially, only the sheriff is known to the other players. Before each round, every player chooses a weapon and then all players simultaneously "shoot" other players by pointing at them. Shots can be deflected or dodged; players take wounds and get healed and take more wounds. Identities become easier to figure out. The sheriff and deputies win by killing the outlaws and vice versa.

A 16-story tower is built, and players each receive four climbing meeples and a hand of three cards to play and replenish. Each player in turn plays one card and moves one of his meeples up the tower the number of stories shown on the card. A few special cards modify this rule. Meeples that are landed on fall to the bottom and start over. The first player whose meeples all reach the top is the winner.

Players in æ¡œ (Sakura) want to empty their hand of cards before anyone else. Each player starts with 7-10 cards, and the sakura petal-shaped cards come in four suits with three types of special cards.

On a turn, you can play one card to the table to start a new bloom (with up to three blooms being in play at once), add one or more matching cards to an existing bloom (with no more than five cards in the bloom), play a special card, or (if you can't play anything) discard one card, then draw one. If you place the fifth card in a bloom, remove those cards, then play one standard card to start a new bloom.

The first player to empty their hand of cards wins!

In the advanced game, continue play until two players have emptied their hands, with the first player scoring 2 points and the second player 1 point. Play multiple rounds, and the player who first has 5 points wins!

Paragon Tactics Arena is a turn-based tactical board game, created by G. Scary T., where 2 to 4 players lead characters in an arena fight to determine who the best tactician is. Between so many enemies and obstacles, your characters cannot move freely. You must command them through action cards you draw during the combat, making the card management even more challenging than the battle itself. Each player must control his/her party strategically to better use each character’s powers and abilities and defeat all enemies. Do you think you have what it takes to lead your characters alive through this deadly skirmish?

Game Aspects:
- Easy Learning
- Tactics and Strategy
- Card Management
- Changeable and Customizable Board
- Replayability
- Easily House Ruled 
- Expandable (more characters on the way!)

Rumble is a customizable discard game, where the goal of the game is to get rid of all your cards before your opponents and become the RUMBLE MASTER!  There are 90 cards in a RUMBLE deck and contains 10 different RUMBLER cards in 4 colors (red, blue, green, and yellow) and 10 wild RAINBOW CARDS.  By adding expansions called "RUMBLE PACKS" it’s possible to create your own custom games with brand new RUMBLERS to do battle with!

The Mulberry Bush Game is a roll and move game for young children. Land on a picture of a teddy getting ready for school, mime the action (eg brushing teeth, putting on coat) and you get to collect the card. The first player to collect all 6 cards is the winner!
